{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2974880,"name":"Srinivas Deva","username":"srinivasdeva","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/b9e5f3/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-11-04T02:53:57.274Z","cooked":"

My question is more of a hypothetical one involving advanced mechanisms in which they act on each other. For example, say there is an elevator mounted on a turret. Let’s say I tune the elevator to go to a specific height using motion magic individually (meaning with the turret stationary) and then tune the turret to turn to a specific angle individually (with the elevator stationary). In this case, if I set the setpoint of the elevator and the turret simultaneously, they will be moving at the same time, but I think this will make the mechanisms act differently than when we tuned them individually. The problem might be further exacerbated when there are even more external forces acting on the system such as the robot being in motion. Is my concern valid, and if so are there any ways to deal with this type of motion other than making the mechanisms move to a specific setpoint in a sequential manner? Or do Motion magic/PID end up performing well enough in practice in these situations at least for FRC?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2021-11-04T02:55:06.920Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":192,"reads":240,"readers_count":239,"score":1008.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":397039,"topic_slug":"does-motion-magic-and-or-standard-pid-work-consistently-when-there-are-external-forces-acting-on-the-mechanism","display_username":"Srinivas Deva","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49088,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/does-motion-magic-and-or-standard-pid-work-consistently-when-there-are-external-forces-acting-on-the-mechanism/397039/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2974885,"name":"Anand Rajamani","username":"asid61","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/asid61/{size}/7179_2.png","created_at":"2021-11-04T03:52:17.966Z","cooked":"

If things performed the same every single time, they wouldn’t need a control loop - you could just apply static voltages to move things around.

As it stands, we live in an imperfect world, so control loops are needed to act against outside forces. Those could be friction that increases over time from wear and tear, game piece weight, mechanism changes, etc. PID loops will absolutely do the trick to recover from these disturbances. Motion Magic and Motion Profiling in general, with strong feedforward terms, does a great job controlling position. If your mechanisms are extremely powerful or heavy (like a sideways turret mounted on an elevator from 2019) then it might become more difficult to tune, but it should still recover just fine.

My rule of thumb is to never exceed ~20% of a motor’s stall current or 20A per motor on any mechanism, whichever is lower. This leaves a ton of room for the control loop to mess around and virtually guarantees controllability in the FRC space. This isn’t universally true, of course, but for all but your most outlandish robots there should be no problem controlling it unless the drive current becomes very high (indicating other problems at play).

For your example of an elevator and a turret, most likely those wouldn’t affect each other at all if they are not trying to move things in the same direction. If the turret was sideways and poorly counterweighted like a bad 2019 implementation, then it might be more difficult to control, but probably still possible (just maybe slower than a properly counterweighted one).

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2021-11-04T03:53:35.755Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":240,"readers_count":239,"score":63.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":397039,"topic_slug":"does-motion-magic-and-or-standard-pid-work-consistently-when-there-are-external-forces-acting-on-the-mechanism","display_username":"Anand Rajamani","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":21715,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/does-motion-magic-and-or-standard-pid-work-consistently-when-there-are-external-forces-acting-on-the-mechanism/397039/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2974894,"name":"Giora Kornblau ","username":"kornblau","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kornblau/{size}/160607_2.png","created_at":"2021-11-04T10:47:04.626Z","cooked":"
asid61:

a great job controlling position. If your mechanisms are extremely powerful or heavy (li

our (1690) experience with these types of situations is that with enough over-power the motion magic / PID are good enough for most cases without any tricks.
but …
this year, we had a large and heavy shooter arm that we wanted to open within 0.8 seconds to +/-0.1 degree of the wanted angle for all angles and during driving. the arm was driven with one RS775pro motor.
we used motion magic … but …
in order to get the performance for all arm angles and drive accelerations, we found ourselves doing the following:

  • calculate the torque on the arm due to gravitational force (proportional to the cosine of the real time arm angle)
  • calculate the torque on the arm due to the driving acceleration (we use swerve so took the projection of the acceleration in the direction of the shooter and multiply by the sine of the real-time arm angle)
  • calculate the torque on the arm due to acceleration of the shooter wheels
  • add the above torques, and “predict” to the time that the command will be executed by the Talon
  • add “arbitrary feed forward” to the motion magic that is proportional to the total torque at the future time (when the command will be executed)

the improvement we saw with this concept was huge - both in the time to stabilize the arm, but also in the stability of the arm during driving.
we met the 0.8 second / 0.1 degree requirement

It’s all about the feedforward. If the loop is doing the bulk of the work, it won’t perform particularly well. The loop should only handle things you don’t know about beforehand.
